A protected natural harbour on the west coast of North Sumatra, Sibolga is close to the

archipelago and to thickly forested mountains. Around the turn of the 20th century it was an old trading port under English and then Dutch administration.

Its general layout is as follows:

value: To the north, a road follows the bay to various villages which are less developed than the centre of town. Fisher folk seem to live here. There is also a large industrial facility if you keep going. You can hire a
to get up here and poke around.
To the northeast, the old road curves up over the mountains towards
In the centre of town, the western waterfront has some small residential areas and a school. There's a playing field and the major bus station, which adjoins the market (
). West of the market are a couple of streets that have been converted to a market extension fruit vending area.
To the southeast lies the major port which has boats to

The town is small enough to walk around but there's an oversupply of
(motorbike sidecars) available for a small fee (think Rp 3,000).

value: A fishing village a short distance northwest along the bay.

If you hire a motorbike, hitch or travel a small distance by bus, there are good views of town from the main road northwards up the mountains.

Wikipedia asserts that a former English/Dutch fort used to exist on Poncan Ketek Island ("small Poncan island') in the bay and you could hire a boat to take you there.

In town there are plenty of
including a large new one under construction towards the waterfront, plus at least one
. At least three other temples are also present. One of these, a
, the Mahayana Buddhist Boddhisattva of compassion, is on what seems to be the former main Chinese street (now an evening food/drink stall street). The

is more traditional Chinese (ie, more Confucian/Daoist, less Buddhist, but actually includes Buddhist also) slightly to the southeast of there, featuring a large statue of a tiger and backing on to a school. A
dedicated to Maitreya (the future Buddha) is in the north just off the main road, with a prominent

sign visible from the street, however it may be permanently closed.

If you are careful when poking around you might notice some

value: (bazaar, or market) of Sibolga. View from the west (ie. direction of the coast).

where the majority of fishing boats are moored may be entertaining.
There's really not a lot to do. Some locals swim in the water near the Hotel Wisata Indah, but it's neither particularly clean nor private.

value: , a kind of night time street food market. The same street used to be the historic Chinese quarter, and many of the businesses are still owned by descendents of Chinese immigrants. (

There's a market behind the bus station which is good for provisioning. Some areas of town have interesting garments on offer, and there seems to be a fair supply of tailors.

value: Detail of a few of the products on offer at a potions and tonics stall: if you're in the market for improving your (wo)manliness, a stall at Sibolga Square in the evening offers a great selection.
Typical street food stall in Sibolga Square, with blender and tropical fruits, and a wok for fried rice and noodles.
A freshly prepared, Sibolga Square, 'vegetarian' version of

, a fried sort of wide flat rice-noodle with egg, chilli and spring onion derived from the (predominantly Cantonese/Hokkien) Chinese immigrants. This dish was flavoured with a thick soy-looking sauce (of a type typical of Indonesia), plus MSG and salt, and garnished with prawn crackers and slices of tomato and cucumber. The noodles are rice flower based and reminiscent of 米干 (
) of the Tai peoples. They could also be likened to the 粉丝 (

) of the modern Han Chinese, but thinner. Unlike either of those traditions, however, the integrity of the length of the noodles do not seem to be considered during preparation, leading to very short pieces after frying.The vegetarian version is identical to the meat version except that small pieces of splayed, separately cooked chicken meat are not dropped on top prior to serving.

cuisine, with some of them offering a fair number of vegetarian options.
here as nobody uses them and their motivation to please customers is earth-shatteringly low. The old Chinese street,
, is a good venue for evening meals outdoors, featuring satay (
), rice and noodle dishes as well as numerous fruit juice and proximity to friendly beer-vending Chinese storepeople.
) stalls are dotted around town. The going rate is Rp 7,000 per juice at day time stands. At night in Sibolga Square (the old Chinese street) the price is Rp 10,000.
is available in most of the hotels and some stores, though rarely refrigerated, and can be drunk in public within some social limits.

There are quite a few hotels dotted around the north-western part of town. Prices seem to range from around Rp 160,000 through Rp 280,000 per night, some have wireless internet (generally only near the lobby), and some have hot water. There appears to be something new under construction as well.

value: directions=50m south of the northwestern end of Sibolga Square (the old Chinese street).

content=The only relatively comfortable hotel in town featuring both hot water and internet. Newly built circa 2012. Overpriced, but the location is nice for evening visits to Sibolga Sq and in its class it's essentially the only thing going.
address=On the harbour, northwest of town.

content=Outdoes itself in generously distributing waste about its corridors and gardens, failing to provide either hot water or any vegetarian edible breakfast (even rice) and hiring perfectly disinterested staff. Extremely poor value for money.

Some hotels and a very small number of restaurants have Wi-Fi. There are some computer game/internet cafés in town as well.

is the main destination, which is reachable by either of two ferries. Tickets for both can be acquired at the entrance to the port (safest), or on the boat itself (possibly not a good idea for the fast boat).

value: Fast passenger ferry. Departs 09:00. c. 3hr. Rp 150,000pp
